review_title: Great org being ruined by senior management
pros: - The work being done is impactful and innovative, and empowers local partners without making them reliant on outside aid - Most of the staff is welcoming, friendly, and helpful - Recently voted to unionize; union very much has your back - Great benefits
cons: - Senior exec is doing their best to union bust; which is ironic considering that we are a pro-democracy organization. They've made the work environment uncomfortable and at times almost hostile, not to mention a number of inappropriate comparisons - Not very accepting of "invisible" disabilities that affect work. Requesting accommodations is relatively easy/straightforward, but even with accommodations, senior staff will form negative opinions of you based on how you're "falling short" due to disability - Management wants everyone to be back in the office as much as possible despite the majority of staff's objections; not flexible on this - Poor work-life balance (as with most nonprofits) - The Board has way too much say, especially considering some of the people on it (looking at you Ken Blackwell); however, new appointments to the Board in recent years has improved things

pros: IFES at this point gets by entirely thanks to its dedicated staff and experts so you'll meet a lot of smart, dedicated, and kind people in HQ and in-country offices (read: not executive leadership or the board who in many cases actively harm IFES initiatives and staff) Lots of work-related travel opportunities including for junior staff. Programs are interesting and provide opportunity for technical advancement (if you aren't so overworked that you don't have time to focus on anything but dealing with HR and admin issues) Softball league.
cons: - extremely strict and unfair return to office policy (in Crystal City, no less), after throwing out a survey where staff indicated desire for remote work flexibility (justified by gaslighting staff into saying remote work slowed down revenue when it's common knowledge the opposite is true) - President/CEO and executive leadership are increasingly hostile to staff, regulating use of email, tracking building swipe entries, and in some cases monitoring personal social media accounts - it's well known that the President/CEO gets rid of staff who are troublesome for him (former HR director, former union leader...) or who demand accountability; the suspicion is that several senior level compliance and finance staff left all around the same time because of this - President/CEO meddles in staff affairs even at the most junior levels -- blocking promotions or forcing them through without regard for the manager's recommendation, or even making up new positions with no recruitment process - extremely high turnover especially among junior and program staff - antiquated HR systems and software are in place; new ones come out after YEARS and are worse than the ones before - contracting and compliance processes are opaque and inefficient; same for finance - cover-ups are frequent for suspected financial mismanagement while junior staff are reprimanded for the smallest inconsistencies - IT department is under-resourced and difficult to work with. Won't even provide a mouse or headphones outside of program funds - little oversight or accountability for higher level positions - extremely high indirect rate and yet benefits and general office perks are worse than most other orgs in the industry - HR is incompetent and unresponsive, have caused multiple financial mismanagement issues and actively harmed programming (hundreds of thousands of $ have been spent on recruiting because the huge HR team cannot do it themselves) - active union-busting and repression of free speech. Won't allow staff to speak in "all staff" meetings, ask questions about the union, or even reply to all-staff emails (even to say goodbye to a colleague who's leaving, for example). - the office itself is unpleasant, no logical organization of offices which causes unproductive workspaces... one coffee machine for the entire office that doesn't work half the time... the wifi is almost nonexistent thanks to executive level approval hangups to get it fixed (for years) - the only IFES spirit or culture comes from events that are organized entirely on junior staff's unpaid labor and time - very low salaries for the market rates, and yearly "merit-based increases" cover less than half of inflation rate at 2-3%, no bonuses or equity adjustments

pros: - Great interaction with in-country partners - work-related travel opportunities
cons: - horrible work life balance - low pay - micromanagers - top level management is arrogant and resistent to change - no investment in professional development

pros: It encourages everyone to do their best and their is always team work.

pros: Some colleagues are mission-driven; the work can (emphasis on “can”) be interesting.
cons: The executive team seem bent on beating staff into submission while ignoring the very real concerns staff raise. 1: Return to the office - leadership has pretended that staff are all chomping at the bit to come back to the office almost full time, and ignored the voluminous evidence to the contrary. A meeting billed as a “town hall to solicit staff feedback” started off with the president informing staff that a decision had already been made so their input wouldn’t matter (that’s almost a verbatim quote). The resulting uproar led to an IFES staff survey on return to office/work from home, the results of which IFES refused to release. The executives have bungled this badly and created massive amounts of resentment and poor morale. 2: IFES’ Executive Team is trying to destroy IFES’ staff union. The executive team spread disinformation, misinformation, and outright lies about the union in the run up to the vote. They also tried to disenfranchise staff from voting, and tried to force Country Directors to advocate against the union as well (luckily, the Country Directors told them to go pound sand). Since IFES staff voted overwhelmingly for a union, IFES has since fired union-member staff for made up reasons (and will now need to waste tons of money on legal costs to defend themselves), refused to meaningfully work with the union to address staff issues, and tries to undercut staff benefits as a way to make the union look like a failure. It’s simply shocking to see an organization whose entire premise is empowering people to have their voices heard, work so hard to suppress the voices of its own staff and not even be shy about it. 3: Staff Turnover - turnover has skyrocketed as the smart folks see the writing on the wall and get out. Average tenure has fallen precipitously from 5+ years to less than one year. IFES touts its “great benefits and pay” but honestly, they’re average at best, as their competitors have more than caught up over the past few years. In the meantime, as the executive team works hard to undermine staff and kill their morale, they continue to make the organization more and more top-heavy with people who make great promises but consistently fail to deliver. IFES is getting closer and closer to financial and operational failure, and doing nothing about it.

pros: IFES is an organization with immense potential. As one of the few organizations working on elections and, by extension, democracy and governance, it is well-placed to have a significant impact on development efforts around the world. The subject matter is itself interesting, and has the potential to make for dynamic, challenging and rewarding programming. The organization attracts, for the most part, talented and enthusiastic staff at the junior and mid levels, leading to an overall relaxed but hard-working atmosphere.
cons: Unfortunately, the organization has become progressively process-driven over the past years, and attention seems to have shifted away from emphasizing strong technical programs and flexibility in favor of rigid systems that are often unrealistic to apply, making it more difficult to successfully implement programs in a timely fashion. This creates a schism between field offices and HQ, where field offices are working to meet the needs of stakeholders, but are having to negotiate in order to meet some of the unrealistic requirements of HQ procedures.  There is a general sense that the organization has gotten more concerned with the potential for audit findings than failing to meet programmatic obligations to donors and stakeholders. There seems to be a high level of distrust between various departments within the organization and there is little transparency.

review_title: Poor management and low staff morale
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Crystal City, VA
pros:
The technical work is very unique and IFES is still the leading provider of technical assistance for elections in developing countries.
If you get to visit field offices, you will realize why the work is important and how IFES in the field is actually much more known and respected than IFES HQ.
A CFO with a good reputation and who seems like he knows what he’s doing. Right now he is the only hope for survival, if he stays on board and manages to fix the unfixable.
cons:
Terrible financial management and incompetence in dealing with foreign currency projects resulted in massive financial losses over the past few years. 
Add to that a lack of commitment to new business development which keeps the win rate of competitive proposals at a very low level. 
A series of layoffs over the past few years have brought staff morale to perhaps an all-time low.
HQ moved from a prime location in downtown DC to being tucked away in Crystal City. To make things worse, the office space is so bizarrely designed that it feels like it was done like this on purpose to break down any meaningful human exchanges between staff.

review_title: IFES is an organization where you can professionally grow, but the emotional toll can be high.
pros: There is generally good potential for professional growth at IFES, particularly for junior and mid-level staff.  Younger employees (20s and 30s) often spend time with each other outside of work (i.e. happy hour, etc.).  And, IFES has one of the nicest offices out of all its competitors.
cons: While senior management has striven to make IFES a better place to work recently, inter-personal issues remain a problem.  These issues have affected trust between divisions, and attempts to overcome the issue have generally focused on policy not personnel.  As a result, IFES DC has become more process-oriented and the workplace morale continues to be low.

review_title: Great if you're posted in the "field"

- There is very little support from the HQ on the substance. The HQ is really only making sure you're in compliance with the requirement of the client. So, if you are not experienced in this field, it can be challenging.
- The company is constantly in a cycle from near collapse to growth. If IFES  would not have relationship with the US government, it would have collapsed  long time ago.

pros: It is a little odd to read reviews of discontent.   This organization like any organization has its share of "Debby Downers," the types that not matter what an organization does will still be unhappy....they're just unhappy people in general.  It's difficult to teach people how to be happy.  I've never understood why people stay at a job when they are unhappy but there always seem to be a few who insist on bringing everyone else down, and I think their unhappiness shows in the way they drone on in reviews. Typically they are underperformers.  Let me just start out by saying that the organization has an extremely low turnover rate and I don't think I've ever seen anyone "released" from the organization for performance.  They always seem to try to work with people to get them where they need to be to do their job.  No one keeps anyone shackled to their desk and they are free to leave at anytime.  The salaries are very competitive and the benefits are second to none for a nonprofit here in Washington, DC.  The work and the people are extremely interesting.  The office is in a great location....downtown DC right on K Street.  Lots of internal continuing education opportunities.
cons: The organization is very structured about the number of years of experience needed to advance to the next level, so if you've got a high self esteem and think that you are smarter than your peers, then this probably isn't a great place for you to be recognized as quickly as you would like.  That being said, they do recognize via promotion those within the organization that are very effective at doing.   After a while you know who the top performers are as well as those who "underperform."

review_title: Lack of vision and rampant favoritism
pros:
The organization is a trademark within the governance industry. On the outside, chiefly because of its international reach, IFES has cemented a reputation of an uncontested authority in elections.
My experience has been great within my own team. Everyone is respectful and listens to others' opinion and we always find support from each others.
cons:
Oh lord! where to begin?
For starters, IFES is a noxious place with a disorder that starts at the executive level. This team consists of, at best clueless members, to dangerously territorial persons who are ready to do anything to protect their positions, often at the expense (literally) of other lower-ranked employees. These people can't even get their finances right and rather than have the decency to step down, they instead go on a witch-hunt against junior team members and have them fired. While they line their pockets with business class travel and end-of-year bonuses, regular employees get timid 3-4% annual increases and benefits keep shrinking.
IFES' executive team created a group of favorites who benefit from getting the cool and interesting assignments. When one of these favorite kids, despite his/her incompetence, get the blessings, s/he get a career fast-track and receive full protection, often at the expense of another and arguably more qualified colleague. 
Senior management started to use similar tactics. The director and deputy in my department are completely clueless and do not do the job they were hired for.
IFES has been on a slippery slope with attempts to get new funding . More shops were closed than open in the past 2 years. That is because new opportunities and innovative ideas are met with a lack of appetite to risk-taking and instead rely on past performance, competitor action , and public reports.

review_title: Demoralizing, limiting, and backstabbing - if I would have known, I wouldn't have accepted the job.
pros: Great health care and vacation benefits. Convenient location, deceivingly-beautiful office space.
cons: Where do I even start....Adults acting like middle schoolers, back-stabbing, framing each other, hoarding policies and keeping them secret, little to no transparency, 92% dissatisfaction in the 2013 employee surveys company-wide, the highest turnover I've ever experienced (9 people quit in the past 2 months). There is really really bad company culture; people haven't forgotten the 11 people were laid off in March, 2013 due to a G&A "crisis" -- NONE were executive staff or senior management, who are the problem, but rather lower-level employees who have been at IFES for decades -- but then the company spent tens of thousands of dollars on useless training, extensive travel for executives, and creation of redundant and unnecessary (high-paid) positions. The CFO was never out of the country before last year, and the President has made it clear that he is putting his time in to make a name for himself, so he can re-join the Democratic party to be a lobbyist. Board members' response to problems with our project in Congo: "Tell us again why we work in those scum bag countries?" All to demonstrate that those in leadership show a lack of understanding, and interest in the work that we do - which is unfortunate, as they are leading a large "non-profit." They are extremely risk adverse and don't allow us to pursue bids unless they are a "sure thing," which results in us turning down interested donors such as the EU. Many employees believe that this is because management is used to being part of the CEPPS consortium, which may or may not be a sure thing in the future - USAID is talking about making it open-source which will undermine IFES' edge. This organization is not ready to be competitive, and I would worry about starting to work here now if you want a job in 5 years. IFES is 70% dependent on USAID funding, and have ZERO Business Development team to speak of....which is unheard of, in and of itself. IFES internal policies are even more stringent than USAID, and this causes them to be inflexible; resulting in unheard-of delays in activity implementation, sub-award procurement, and more. USAID is constantly upset with IFES because of administrative back-logging, and there is a "it's not our problem" attitude from management. The President even requested a letter from USAID "asking IFES to come back to Congo, personally" since they had a "bad experience" there the first time. It just shows a lack of realistic perspective on how Intl Development works, and how donor relationships should function. IFES will get a cold, hard slap to reality eventually, and I am just glad I won't be around to see it when it happens.
